channel.title: WHATWG DOM Workstream-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG DOM Workstream

item.title: [dom, selectors-4] Content suggestion: Example of :scope in element.querySelecotr()
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

What if among examples of element.querySelector()
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/element/querySelector
would be something with :scope in selectors?
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:scope

Why is it important or useful?

It seems relevant, considering there aren’t any other uses for :scope now, and it’s basically the only place it matters at the moment.

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Introduction to events": (when an event is fired modern broser runs three phases not two)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When the author said that modern browsers runs two phases (and not three) when an event is dispatched.
the capturing and bubbling phases does not include the target node.
it can lead the reader to misunderstand some MDN docs explanations, E.g: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation
the above link mentions the capturing and bubbling phases and if the reader has in mind that the target phase is part of the capturing and bubbling phases, it will misunderstand what that method does
https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-eventphase

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events#bubbling_and_capturing_explained

What did you expect to see?

When an event is fired on an element that has parent elements, modern browsers run three different phases — the capturing phase, the target phase and the bubbling phase.

Did you test this? If so, how?

nope

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/learn/javascript/building_blocks/events
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/learn/javascript/building_blocks/events/index.html
  • Last commit: e65944b
  • Document last modified: 2021-06-08T12:51:38.000Z

item.title: [dom] Event.composedPath() refers to nonexistent example
item.content:encoded:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/composedPath says:

In our composed-composed-path example (see it live), we define two trivial custom elements, and ...

...but "(see it live)" doesn't link to anything. I couldn't see anything likely in https://github.com/mdn/dom-examples/, maybe it's somewhere else, or maybe it's just gone?

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Text": Unclear description of when multiple text nodes may be created
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Text

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The documentation for text node says:

New documents have a single Text node for each block of text. Over time, more Text nodes may be created as the document's content changes.

It's unclear whether this is something that the user "may" as in "is allowed to" do or if it is something a browser behavior that "may" as in "might" do as a result of changes to the document.

Specific section or headline?

The introduction part.

What did you expect to see?

If anyone knows more details about how and when multiple text nodes are created, it would be great to have that on this page.

Did you test this? If so, how?

No, I'm not sure if it's referring to a browser trigger that can be triggered somehow or something a user can do.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/text
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Text
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/text/index.html
  • Last commit: f2a9cd2
  • Document last modified: 2021-04-27T06:37:39.000Z

item.title: [dom, web-bluetooth] Content bug: linking macros to Boolean shouldn't be {{domxref}}
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

127 pages (mainly in the Web API references).

For example:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMTokenList/contains
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Bluetooth/requestDevice
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Firefox/Releases/45

Specific page section or heading?

Various sections in various reference pages.

What is the problem?

{{domxref("Boolean")}} is used in a lot of pages.
However I thought it should be {{jsxref("Boolean")}} because Boolean isn't an interface of Web API and actually the {{domxref("Boolean")}} is redirected to the JavaScript reference.

This looks no problem due to redirecting, but it produces broken link in translation versions.

However {{jsxref("Boolean")}} is also incorrect because many of Web APIs use boolean primitive, not a Boolean object.

What did you expect to see?

{{jsxref("Boolean")}}, or another way to show it is a boolean primitive correctly.

Did you test this? If so, how?

item.title: [dom] Content bug: space before on many pages
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

Lots of them!

Specific page section or heading?

Example: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Attr#properties

What is the problem?

There's a space in the code instead of after it, so it shows true instead of true.

Some cases fixed in #3385, but there are too many so I'm filing an issue instead.

item.title: [dom] Document CharacterData
item.content:encoded:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CharacterData is incomplete. None of the sub pages exist but they should. CharacterData is a core DOM API that is well supported and that should have proper docs.

This came up in #2394 where I removed the weird NonDocumentTypeChildNode mixin, so don't worry about that anymore.

CharacterData is the parent interface for Text, ProcessingInstruction, and Comment nodes, so when creating the pages and example code, you probably want to show how to use CharacterData methods like appendData() with something concrete like https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Text nodes.

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Element.classList": Polyfill no longer working on IE 11
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I am experiencing a problem with Element.classList.toggle's polyfill not working. The second argument, force, is ignored on IE 11. It seems like the polyfill may not be applied in this situation. I believe the example has worked in the past.

This can also be reproduce by grabbing the most up-to-date polyfill snippet from MDN and running a basic example.

Specific section or headline?

#polyfill

What did you expect to see?

The force argument to work in IE 11.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Build a test and open in a modern browser and IE 11. You would expect the element to remain red, but the class is instead removed (i.e. the element has no background.)

<style>
  .red {
    background: red;
  }
</style>

<div class="red">
  Red
</div>

<script>
  /**
   * [...]
   * Polyfill from https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList#polyfill
   */
  document.querySelector(".red").classList.toggle("red", true);
</script>

Related: msn0/mdn-polyfills#57

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/element/classlist
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/classList
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/master/files/en-us/web/api/element/classlist/index.html
  • Last commit: 068e0f6
  • Document last modified: 2021-01-25T04:06:51.000Z

item.title: [dom] Browser Compatibility tables are unclear when support for an item has been removed
item.content:encoded:
This is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1417902 filed again for the new MDN setup.

The problem is clearly illustrated by things that were in EdgeHTML (Edge 12-18) but are not in new Chromium-based Edge 79+:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DocumentType#browser_compatibility

It looks as though support was in Edge 12-79, but it was in Edge 12-18.

cc @Elchi3 @ddbeck

item.title: [dom] Issue with "Event.preventDefault()": displayWarning() example doesn't work with autofill
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The displayWarning() example didn't work when I selected my capitalized name from my autofill list

Specific section or headline?

Stopping keystrokes from reaching an edit field > Result

What did you expect to see?

A warning

Did you test this? If so, how?

  1. Open Microsoft Edge (88.0.705.50)
  2. Go to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault
  3. Scroll down to Stopping keystrokes from reaching an edit field > Result
  4. Click the box and select an item with a capital letter
  5. Observe
MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/master/files/en-us/web/api/event/preventdefault/index.html
  • Report started: 2021-01-22T19:11:57.555Z
